question: Pharmacology is the science of drugs and their effects on living systems.
Which of the following is a route of drug administration?
The study of the movement of drugs within the body is called ________.
All drugs have both therapeutic and adverse effects.
What is the primary organ responsible for drug metabolism?
The maximum effect a drug can produce is its ________.
Antibiotics are used to treat viral infections.
Which class of drugs is used to reduce blood pressure?
The term for a drug that blocks the action of another drug is ________.
Half-life is the time it takes for the drug concentration to reduce by half.
What is the main mechanism of action for beta-blockers?
The first-pass effect occurs in the ________.
Placebos have no pharmacological effect.
Which drug is commonly used as an anticoagulant?
The study of drug effects on the body is ________.
Idiosyncratic reactions to drugs are predictable.
What is the therapeutic index?
options: Ratio of toxic dose to effective dose
answer: Ratio of toxic dose to effective dose

question: A drug that mimics the action of a neurotransmitter is an ________.
All drugs require a prescription.
Which enzyme is inhibited by aspirin?
The primary route for drug excretion is the ________.
Tolerance develops with chronic use of some drugs.
What class of drugs includes penicillin?
The volume of distribution indicates the extent of drug ________ in the body.
Generic drugs are always less effective than brand-name drugs.
Which drug is used to treat type 2 diabetes?
An adverse drug reaction that is dose-dependent is called ________.
Pharmacogenetics studies how genes affect drug response.
What is the main side effect of opioids?
The process by which a drug enters the bloodstream is ________.
Over-the-counter drugs require no regulation.
Which class of drugs is used for anxiety?
The ED50 is the dose that produces a response in 50% of the ________.
Drug interactions can only increase effects.
What is the antidote for acetaminophen overdose?
Biotransformation of drugs occurs mainly in the ________.
Controlled substances have no potential for abuse.
Which drug is a proton pump inhibitor?
The blood-brain barrier affects drug ________ to the CNS.
Allergic reactions to drugs are immune-mediated.
What is the primary use of statins?
The term for the unintended effects of a drug is ________ effects.
Phase I clinical trials test drug efficacy.
Which antibiotic class includes ciprofloxacin?
Clearance is the rate at which a drug is ________ from the body.
Herbal supplements have no drug interactions.
What is the mechanism of action for diuretics?
A drug's potency refers to the ________ required to produce an effect.
Vaccines are considered pharmacological agents.
Which drug is used for anticoagulation reversal?
The placenta acts as a barrier to all drugs during ________.
Dependence on a drug can be physical or psychological.
What class of drugs includes morphine?
Bioavailability is highest with ________ administration.
There are presently over 48,000 prescription drugs.
Over 120,000 deaths occur each year resulting from adverse drug reactions.
A DEA number is needed on a prescription for all controlled medications.
Another name for Demerol, a narcotic analgesic, is Meperidine.
Some drugs on the sterile field must be identified and labeled.
The majority of drugs given in the operating room are administered parenterally.
Each drug generally has two names.
The FDA is responsible for monitoring drug development, manufacturing, and marketing.
PDR stands for primary drug resource.
Thrombin can be Injected during emergency situations.
You can increase the hemostatic efficiency of avitene By applying sterile saline to it.
Streptokinase is given IV to dissolve blood clots.
Lasix is the most common osmotic diuretic.
5% dextrose and 0.9% NaCl are isotonic.
Your primary duty as a scrub, during cardiac arrest surgery, is to get help.
The usual dosage of amantadine is 10-40mg daily.
Because of disease such as arthritis, pain is considered a normal part of the aging process.
Patients taking levodopa may notice res to black discoloration of urine.
Pyridoxine will increase the therapeutic effect of levodopa; therefore patients should be told purchase pyridoxine-free vitamins.
Abrupt discontinuation of antiparkinsonian agents may precipitate status epilepticus.
Fibrosis, a rare side effect that causes thickening or scaring of the membranes lining of body organs, has been reported with Parlodel use.
Aricept is a new drug that is used to cure Alzheimer's patients.
Antipsychotic agents may be prescribed for aggressive behavior in Alzheimer's patients.
Phenytoin sodium has been known to cause gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism.
Lidocaine HCl is a commonly used general anesthetic.
Diamox is an oral diuretic that is used in the treatment of glaucoma.
Phenergan Tigan may be given orally, rectally, or by IM injection.
Patients taking any hormone therapy should report weight gain of 5 pounds or more in a week to their physician.
Testosterone use in woman may cause virilization, in women take on masculine characteristics.
Patients taking testosterone are at increased risk of developing blood clots, as testosterone increases certain clotting factors.
Hepatic flow-dependent drug elimination refers to:
options: rate-limiting step is drug delivery to hepatic elimination sites
answer: rate-limiting step is drug delivery to hepatic elimination sites

question: Cytochrome P450 induction (increased, amount of P450 enzyme protein) is often associated with:
Microsomal drug metabolizing enzymes are typically associated with:
Examples of "high-extraction" drugs -- related to hepatic drug clearance:
Pharmacogenetic effects:
options: prolonged mivacurium-induced neuromuscular blockade due to atypical cholinesterase
succinylcholine or volatile anesthetic-induced malignant hyperthermia

question: Termination of pharmacological action of thiopental occurs mainly by:
Reaction type associated with inactivation of succinylcholine, atracurium, and mivacurium.
Factors affecting renal clearance of drugs:
Concerning drug-plasma protein binding:
options: Drugs are seldom bound to plasma proteins
volume of distribution is not influenced by protein binding
diazepam is an example of the drug that is minimally protein-bound
drug clearance is influenced by the extent of protein binding
answer: drug clearance is influenced by the extent of protein binding

question: Mixed function oxidases system is referred to as mediating:
Factors affecting renal drug secretion rates:
options: drug transfer rates across tubular membranes

question: Which of the following is the antidote for the toxin Benzodiazepines?

Which of the following drugs is associated with the reaction of hepatitis?

Which of the following drugs is associated with the reaction of Tendon dysfunction?

A drug ending in the suffix (azole) is considered a ______.
A drug ending in the suffix (tidine) is considered a ______.

Which of the following drugs is associated with the reaction of extreme photosensitivity?

Which of the following is considered a class IA Sodium Channel blocker?
Pharmacology is the study of drugs, which includes understanding how drugs are administered, where they travel in the body, and the ________ they produce.
In order to thoroughly understand pharmacology, related subjectsâ€”such as anatomy and physiology, chemistry, microbiology, and __________ must be understood as well.
Therapeutics is concerned with the prevention of disease and treatment of _______.
Traditional drugs are ___________ agents synthesized in a laboratory that produce biological responses in the body.
Biologics are naturally produced in animal cells, by microorganisms or by the _______ itself, and are used to treat a variety of illnesses and conditions.
Prescription drugs offer the advantage of the patient's being ________ by a health care provider, as well as ensuring that the proper amount and frequency of a drug are prescribed.
Advantages of Over-the-Counter (OTC drugs) include the ability to obtain the drug ___________ seeing a health care provider.
The Food and Drug Administration was officially established as an agency of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services in _______.
Any pharmaceutical laboratory must solicit approval from the FDA __________ marketing a drug.
The FDA reviews therapeutic and biologic drugs for approval in four phases: preclinical investigation, _________investigation, review of the New Drug Application (NDA), and postmarketing _________.
The clinical investigation, which is the ________ part of the drug-approval process, evaluates the drug's effectiveness and safety in humans.
The average NDA _________ time is 17 to 24 months.
A client who has paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia received an IV dysrhythmic, _______.
A man who has urinary hesitation and dysuria is prescribe ______ to relieve these symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
A client who has atrial fibrillation is prescribed ______ to prevent thrombosis.
A client who has epilepsy takes _______.
A woman who has a trichomoniasis infection takes _______.
A client who has muscle spasm is prescribed _______.
______ may be given for antidepressant induced insomnia.
A client is prescribed oral ______ for pain control.
A client who has asthma is instructed to take ______ two hours before exercising to prevent bronchospasms.
